chapter.title: Resizable Dialogs
chapter.para: In the early versions of Windows, dialogs in general were always fixed in size. Even today, most dialogs are fixed in size. However, the use of resizable dialogs has become very common. Giving the user the ability to resize the dialogs in your program is a nice feature. Especially if the dialogs contain list boxes, list-views, or tree-views.
ooDialog provides two basic ways to make dialogs resizable. One is through the class and the other is through the class.

section.title: DlgArea Class
section.para: The DlgArea class provides assistance in laying out the dialog controls in a dynamically defined dialog. The class defines an area within the of a . It is a helper class for the method of a UserDialog and has no effect on any window.
Note that the DlgArea class does not, in and of itself, produce a resizable dialog. It is the use of its subclass, the class that produces a resizable dialog.

The methods and attributes of the DlgArea provide the coordinates of, and within, the defined area. All coordinates are specified as client area coordinates. That is, all coordinates are relative to the origin (0, 0) of the client area of the dialog.

section.title: init
section.para: Instantiates a new DlgArea object.

listitem.para:
The arguments are:
x [required]
The x coordinate for the area to be defined. The coordinate is specified in s and is relative to the top left corner of the of the UserDialog.
y [required]

section.title: cx
section.para: Returns a width, in dialog units, relative to the width of the dialog area. The cx and methods are synonomous.

listitem.para:
The single argument is:
flag [optional]
The flag argument signals what part of the width to return.
If the flag is omitted, then the entire width of the dialog area, excluding the margins, is returned. If flag is not omitted, it should be one of the following symbols:
n%
Where n is a number and the percent sign signals that a percentage of the dialog area width should be returned. E.g., 10% would mean to return 10 percent of the dialog area width. 8% would ask for 8 percent of the width, etc..
R
A capital R indicates the remainder of the dialog area width should be returned. I.e., that portion of the width between the last invocation of the method and the right margin.
The return is part, or all, of the dialog area width as specified by the flag argument.
Rigours error checking of the argument is not done. If the argument is not recognized it is just ignored and treated as if the argument was omitted.

section.title: x
section.para: Returns a x coordinate relative to the of the dialog by specifying an offset relative to the defined dialog area.

listitem.para:
The single argument is:
offset [optional]
If offset is omitted, then the x coordinate of the left margin is returned.
Otherwise, offset is specified as either a concrete number or as a percentage. To specify a percentage add the percent sign to the number, e.g. for twenty percent use 20%.
In addition, offset can be negative or positive. When positive, the offset is an amount to the right of the left margin. When negative, the offset is an amount to the left of the right margin. Both concrete and percentage offsets can be negative.
The appropriate x coordinate, in dialog units, as specified by the offset argument.

section.title: y
section.para: Returns a y coordinate relative to the of the dialog by specifying an offset relative to the defined dialog area.

listitem.para:
The single argument is:
offset [optional]
If offset is omitted, then the y coordinate of the top margin is returned.
Otherwise, offset is specified as either a concrete number or as a percentage. To specify a percentage add the percent sign to the number, e.g. for twenty percent use 20%.
In addition, offset can be negative or positive. When positive, the offset is an amount below the top margin. When negative, the offset is an amount above the bottom margin. Both concrete and percentage offsets can be negative.
The appropriate y coordinate, in dialog units, as specified by the offset argument.

section.title: DlgAreaU Class
section.para: The DlgAreaU class is a subclass of the class that helps with the creation of dynamically resizable dialogs. This class provides assistance in resizing and / or positioning controls when a dialog is resized. When the DlgArea and DlgAreaU classes are used together, the they provide a convenient way to create resizable dialogs.

Note: The DlgAreaU class uses the .Object class's source class method to parse the source code of the dialog's method. This source is not available if the rexxc program is used to tokenize the source code. Therefore, DlgAreaU class will not work if rexxc is used to tokenize the source code.

The other implication of using the source method to parse the dialog's defineDialog method is that the DlgAreaU class can only be used with a . It will not work with any other dialog class, such as the or classes.

section.title: correctionFactor (Attribute)
section.para: An attribute containing the value used to adjust the ratio of the top & left margins to the bottom & right margins. (The default correction factor is set to 1.05.) The Possible Problems section has additional details on using the correctionFactor attribute.

section.title: lastError (Attribute)
section.para: An attribute holding the details if an error was encountered when parsing the calling dialog's method. The value of the attribute is .nil if no error occurred.

section.title: noMove (Attribute)
section.para: A .Set object holding the resource IDs of the dialog controls that the programmer does not wish to be moved during a resize event. The IDs in the set must be numeric.

The programmer can use IDs for the dialog controls by adding to the set through the method. Or by passing in a .Set object when instantiating a DlgAreaU object. If the programmer accesses the set of IDs directly through the noMove attribute to add a resource ID, only numeric IDs should be used.

section.title: noResize (Attribute)
section.para: A .Set object holding the resource IDs of the dialog controls that the programmer does not wish to be resized during a resize event. The IDs in the set must be numeric.

The programmer can use IDs for the dialog controls by adding to the set through the method. Or by passing in a .Set object when instantiating a DlgAreaU object. If the programmer accesses the set of IDs directly through the noResize attribute to add a resource ID, only numeric IDs should be used.

section.title: updateOnResize (Attribute)
section.para: An attribute that controls whether the DlgAreaU object forces the dialog controls to redraw during every resize event. The default value of this attribute is .true, the dialog controls are forced to redraw on every resize event. Setting this attribute to false will prevent the dialog controls from being forced to redraw.

When the updateOnResize attribute is .false, it becomes the programmer's responsibility to force the dialog controls to redraw when the user has stopped resizing the dialog. This can be down by using the method. Having the dialog controls redraw only once eliminates flicker while the user is sizing the dialog. However, the dialog controls do not change size or position while the using is sizing the dialog. In the samples\oodialog directory of the ooRexx installation are two example programs: dlgAreaUDemo.rex redraws the dialog controls on every resize event. dlgAreaUDemoTwo.rex only redraws the controls once, when the user has stopped resizing the controls. Contrast the two programs to determine which method best suits the needs or your program.

section.title: resize
section.para: The resize method causes the DlgAreaU object to resize and reposition all the dialog controls in the dlgObj dialog in relation to the sizeInfo argument. Normally the dialog is then told to update itself, which redraws the controls. However, the updating is dependent on the value of the attribute.

listitem.para:
The arguments are:
dlgObj [required]
The dialog which is being resized. The dialog must be the same dialog used to instantiate the DlgAreaU object.
sizeInfo [required]
The new size of the dialog. Normally, sizeInfo comes from the value passed to your resize event handler.
This method does not return a value.

The most common way to use the DlgAreaU class is to connect the event to an event handling method in a resizable dialog. Then the sizeInfo arg to the event handler is simply passed on to the resize method.

This example shows a typical event handling method in a resizable dialog that makes use of the DlgAreaU class
::method defineDialog expose u
self~connectResize('onResize')
u = .dlgAreaU~new(self) ...
::method onResize unguarded expose u use arg sizeEvent, sizeInfo
u~resize(self, sizeInfo) return 0

section.title: Creating resizable Dialogs
section.para: You can use the DlgAreaU class to facilitate creating dynamically resizable dialogs. However the following restrictions apply:
The dialog must be a with all dialog controls created in the dialog template from within the method. In the or method, the dialog template must be created with the THICKFRAME option.

You must connect the event to a method in your dialog. Add the following code somewhere in your dialog code. The init, defineDialog or initDialog methods are all a suitable place for the line. The methodName argument is the name of your event handling method and can be any appropriate method name.
Your defineDialog method must start with these lines:
Your defineDialog method must not reference variables within the create/> control method parameters. Although you can use references to attributes, so
section.programlisting: self~createPushButton(IDC_PB, 5, 100, 45, 15, , "MyButton", "Pressed") self~createPushButton(IDC_PB_1, b~x, b~y("10%"), b~w, b~h("9%"), , "Button" 1, "Button"||1)
section.para: work fine, whereas
section.programlisting: /* Seven buttons evenly spaced at 10% intervals, 9% high */ do i = 0 to 6 self~createPushButton(12+i, b~x, b~y((i * 10)||"%"), b~w, b~h("9%"), , "Button" i, "Button"||i) end /* DO */
section.para: would fail because the createPushButton method references the variable i within its parameters.
To debug your DlgAreaU object call/insert the following after the instantiation:
section.programlisting: if u~lastError \= .nil then call errorDialog u~lastError
section.para: Your event handler code for the RESIZE event must pass on the second argument of the method to the DlgAreaU object's resize method.

All of these dialog controls can be added to the dialog template by using combinations of the methods recognized in the resize method.

section.title: Possible Problems
section.para: The DlgAreaU method can create slightly over-size margins on the left & bottom of the Dialog. To correct for this the DlgAreaU class has a attribute set by default to 1.05. In tests, this correction factor appears to neutralise the effect. If your dialogs have over (or under) sized margins, you may be able to correct this in your code by adjusting the correctionFactor attribute. For example:
You will have to experiment to find the appropriate setting for this attribute.
This problem occurs because of the use of the factorX and factorY attributes to convert pixels to dialog units. Fixing the problem, at this point, would most likely break existing programs.

section.title: ResizingAdmin Mixin Class
section.para: The ResizingAdmin class is a mixin class. Resizable dialogs are produced by having a dialog class inherit the ResizingAdmin class. This makes any ooDialog dialog resizable without having to change any code in the dialog, even existing dialog. With one caveat, and dialogs are not supported at this time.
